channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [PDFBOX-2714] Type1Fonts working on one computer, not another
item.description:
Asked on SO, Tilman suggests I open a JIRA: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/29111310/pdfbox-2-0-0-type1fonts-working-on-one-computer-not-another

I am trying to work out why I'm getting a bunch of `java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: No glyph for U+0057 in font Helvetica-Bold` errors on a Windows 2012 Server dev environment, but not on my local Windows 7 environment.

I built the trunk from scratch, with: `mvn -DskipTests=true install`
on my machine (Win 7), collected the jars and made a very rudimentary test package, by dumping all the jars into a subfolder libs/ and copying the `org/apache/pdfbox/examples `class files to the same directory, to see if the HelloWorld program works.

The [HelloWorld program][1] creates a file, called test.pdf with the message "WHY" as requested, but when I run it on a new machine, I get the following:

C:\EAP-6.3.0\PDFBOXTESTING>java -cp ".;libs/*" org.apache.pdfbox.examples.pdmodel.HelloWorld test.pdf WHY
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: No glyph for U+0057 in font Helvetica-Bold
at org.apache.pdfbox.pdmodel.font.PDType1Font.encode(PDType1Font.java:303)
at org.apache.pdfbox.pdmodel.font.PDFont.encode(PDFont.java:268)
at org.apache.pdfbox.pdmodel.PDPageContentStream.showText(PDPageContentStream.java:316)
at org.apache.pdfbox.examples.pdmodel.HelloWorld.main(HelloWorld.java:59)

I installed Adobe Reader XI on that computer, in case it needed the fonts from Adobe, installed on the system, or who knows.

It's not finding `U+0057`, which is a W, and in my testing, it wasn't finding a bunch of stuff. It basically didn't find anything. so something is fundamentally wrong, maybe the operating system has provided a bad font?

[1]: https://github.com/apache/pdfbox/blob/trunk/examples/src/main/java/org/apache/pdfbox/examples/pdmodel/HelloWorld.java
item.summary: Type1Fonts working on one computer, not another

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
I also asked that you show what arial fonts you have. For me, this would be

      773.852 arial.ttf
      750.216 arialbd.ttf
      562.728 arialbi.ttf
      557.004 ariali.ttf
      175.956 ARIALN.TTF
      180.740 ARIALNB.TTF
      180.084 ARIALNBI.TTF
      181.124 ARIALNI.TTF
   23.275.812 ARIALUNI.TTF

My working computer is similar to yours:
773,852 arial.ttf
750,216 arialbd.ttf
562,728 arialbi.ttf
557,004 ariali.ttf
173,936 ARIALN.TTF
178,864 ARIALNB.TTF
178,316 ARIALNBI.TTF
179,368 ARIALNI.TTF
23,275,812 ARIALUNI.TTF

The bad computer has the following:
895,200 arial.ttf
857,344 arialbd.ttf
630,804 arialbi.ttf
635,860 ariali.ttf
167,476 ariblk.ttf

Is Helvetica based on the system's Arial font?
Yes, because Helvetica isn't available on windows. Please attach arialbd.ttf to this issue.
This is the Arial Bold from WinServer2012

I'm assigning this to our font specialist. The font has a postscript table version 3
http://www.microsoft.com/typography/otspec/post.htm
which means "none".
Using the ttf directly works fine as a workaround/replacement for the indirect solution. Have a look at the HelloWorldTTF example to see how it works.

This pdf contains "Hello This Is A Test" but the text is not rendered on my android device. It appears on my windows machine that created the doc when the doc is viewed w/acrobat reader. I can search for the text in the android viewer and a rectangle at the appropriate location is highlighted but no letters are displayed there. Font was added like

PDFont font = PDType0Font.load(document, new File("C:\\windows\\fonts
arial.ttf"));

I am able to view the file on my android phone with the Adobe and the Polaris viewers, but not with the google viewer.

There is a demo PDF/A-1b file in the project (if you run the tests, it will be at PDFBox reactor\examples\target\test-output), that one I can display with all three viewers. However that file was created on my PC on W7.

PDFA.pdf is the file created with the CreatePDFA example. It validates with preflight and PDF-Tools. I can view it on android with Acrobat and Polaris viewers, but not with the Google viewer. I have submitted a bug report.
Yeah that's a Google bug? Thanks for reporting it to them.
Do you have the same issue with the HelloWorldTTF example?
There was a bug with v3 post tables, but I fixed it in PDFBOX-2650.
Yes
I wonder if the bug happens with google pdfium. If yes, then there's another place to report the bug.

Exception in thread "main" java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: No glyph for U+0057 in font Helvetica-Bold
	at org.apache.pdfbox.pdmodel.font.PDType1Font.encode(PDType1Font.java:322)
	at org.apache.pdfbox.pdmodel.font.PDFont.encode(PDFont.java:268)
	at org.apache.pdfbox.pdmodel.PDPageContentStream.showText(PDPageContentStream.java:316)
	at org.apache.pdfbox.examples.pdmodel.HelloWorld.main(HelloWorld.java:59)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:597)
	at com.intellij.rt.execution.application.AppMain.main(AppMain.java:134)

I have managed to reproduce this issue on my Mac using the attached font. Will investigate.
Yes it does! I just tried with Chrome, and the three PDFs attached to this issue are blank. I can select the text and copy/paste it, but not see it.

So I figured out what the problem was. There are hinting instructions in arialbd.ttf which use the cvt and fpgm tables, however in our subset font the cvt table is missing. This is due to a typo in TrueTypeEmbedder, where "cvt" should have been four characters: "cvt ", with a trailing space.

Acrobat and other viewers ignore the invalid hints but PDFium renders the glyphs as blank - that's still worth reporting to them as a bug, though technically it was our fault.

Commit 1668971 from jahewson in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1668971 ]

PDFBOX-2714: Fix typo in TTF subsetter which cause "cvt " table to be removed
Turns out it was a PDFBox bug, see below. Still worth Google addressing this though, as other PDF viewers could handle our subsetted TTFs.

Commit 1668977 from jahewson in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1668977 ]

PDFBOX-2714: Map glyph names when encoding a Type 1 font backed by a TTF

Commit 1668979 from jahewson in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1668979 ]

PDFBOX-2714: Allow base 14 fonts to use the fallback mechanism

Ok, so the problem was that we weren't mapping glyph names to the target font when encoding. This is necessary when the font has a v3 post table (as Tilman noted). We were previously doing this when reading fonts, but not when writing them. This is only an issue for Type 1 fonts backed by a TTF.
This fixes the blank PDFs in Android / Chrome.
This fixes the "No glyph for U+0057 in font Helvetica-Bold" exception.
This fixes a related issue I found when testing, that an NPE occurs on a system with no known base 14 fonts, instead of using the built-in fallback font.

Thanks for all the work on this. Classic "works on my machine" bug. I will try the latest build soon -

Will Pdfbox 2.0.0-SNAPSHOT's Type1Fonts work on the computer with the v3 font now? Or must I still load the working Windows 7 font using the PDType0Font.load() mechanism, as the workaround suggested?

Yes, Type 1 fonts will now work correctly with the v3 font. Note that PDType0Font.load() is the preferred method of using fonts with PDFBox, as it has full Unicode and embedding support, whereas PDType1Font does not.
There should be some test to secure this for the future. Or a way to force it to be length 4.
A unit test would be a good idea.

I had to use the direct TTF loading workaround, because the code recompiled with the latest from 'mvn clean install' is still getting errors on the computer with the v3 fonts. I'm happy with the workaround though.
You remembered to do 'svn update' first, right?
